Language

Main articles: Russian language and Languages of Russia
Minority languages across Russia
Altaic and Uralic languages spoken across Russia
The North Caucasus is ethno-linguistically diverse.[463]

Russian is the official and the predominantly spoken language in Russia.[3] It is the most spoken native language in Europe, the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the world's most widely spoken Slavic language.[464] Russian is one of two official languages aboard the International Space Station,[465] as well as one of the six official languages of the United Nations.[464]

Russia is a multilingual nation; approximately 100–150 minority languages are spoken across the country.[466][467] According to the Russian Census of 2010, 137.5 million across the country spoke Russian, 4.3 million spoke Tatar, and 1.1 million spoke Ukrainian.[468] The constitution gives the country's individual republics the right to establish their own state languages in addition to Russian, as well as guarantee its citizens the right to preserve their native language and to create conditions for its study and development.[469] However, various experts have claimed Russia's linguistic diversity is rapidly declining due to many languages becoming endangered.[470][471]

Religion

Main article: Religion in Russia

Russia is a secular state by constitution, and its largest religion is Eastern Orthodox Christianity, chiefly represented by the Russian Orthodox Church.[7] Orthodox Christianity, together with Islam, Buddhism, and Paganism (either preserved or revived), are recognised by Russian law as the traditional religions of the country, part of its "historical heritage".[472][473]

Islam is the second-largest religion in Russia, and is the traditional religion among the majority of the peoples of the North Caucasus, and among some Turkic peoples scattered along the Volga-Ural region.[7] Large populations of Buddhists are found in Kalmykia, Buryatia, Zabaykalsky Krai, and they are the vast majority of the population in Tuva.[7] Many Russians practise other religions, including Rodnovery (Slavic Neopaganism),[474] Assianism (Scythian Neopaganism),[475] other ethnic Paganisms, and inter-Pagan movements such as Ringing Cedars' Anastasianism,[476] various movements of Hinduism,[477] Siberian shamanism[478] and Tengrism, various Neo-Theosophical movements such as Roerichism, and other faiths.[479][480] Some religious minorities have faced oppression and some have been banned in the country;[481] notably, in 2017 the Jehovah's Witnesses were outlawed in Russia, facing persecution ever since, after having been declared an "extremist" and "nontraditional" faith.[482]

In 2012, the research organisation Sreda, in cooperation with the Ministry of Justice, published the Arena Atlas, an adjunct to the 2010 census, enumerating in detail the religious populations and nationalities of Russia, based on a large-sample country-wide survey. The results showed that 47.3% of Russians declared themselves Christians—including 41% Russian Orthodox, 1.5% simply Orthodox or members of non-Russian Orthodox churches, 4.1% unaffiliated Christians, and less than 1% Old Believers, Catholics or Protestants—25% were believers without affiliation to any specific religion, 13% were atheists, 6.5% were Muslims,[b] 1.2% were followers of "traditional religions honouring gods and ancestors" (Rodnovery, other Paganisms, Siberian shamanism and Tengrism), 0.5% were Buddhists, 0.1% were religious Jews and 0.1% were Hindus.[7]

Education

Main article: Education in Russia

Russia has an adult literacy rate of 100%,[484] and has compulsory education for a duration of 11 years, exclusively for children aged 7 to 17–18.[485] It grants free education to its citizens by constitution.[486] The Ministry of Education of Russia is responsible for primary and secondary education, as well as vocational education; while the Ministry of Education and Science of Russia is responsible for science and higher education.[485] Regional authorities regulate education within their jurisdictions within the prevailing framework of federal laws. Russia is among the world's most educated countries, and has the sixth-highest proportion of tertiary-level graduates in terms of percentage of population, at 62.1%.[487] It spent roughly 4.7% of its GDP on education in 2018.[488]

Russia's pre-school education system is highly developed and optional,[489] some four-fifths of children aged 3 to 6 attend day nurseries or kindergartens. Primary school is compulsory for eleven years, starting from age 6 to 7, and leads to a basic general education certificate.[485] An additional two or three years of schooling are required for the secondary-level certificate, and some seven-eighths of Russians continue their education past this level.[490]

Admission to an institute of higher education is selective and highly competitive:[486] first-degree courses usually take five years.[490] The oldest and largest universities in Russia are Moscow State University and Saint Petersburg State University.[491] There are ten highly prestigious federal universities across the country. Russia was the world's fifth-leading destination for international students in 2019, hosting roughly 300 thousand.[492]

Health

Main article: Healthcare in Russia

Russia, by constitution, guarantees free, universal health care for all Russian citizens, through a compulsory state health insurance program.[494] The Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation oversees the Russian public healthcare system, and the sector employs more than two million people. Federal regions also have their own departments of health that oversee local administration. A separate private health insurance plan is needed to access private healthcare in Russia.[495]

Russia spent 5.65% of its GDP on healthcare in 2019.[496] Its healthcare expenditure is notably lower than other developed nations.[497] Russia has one of the world's most female-biased sex ratios, with 0.859 males to every female,[10] due to its high male mortality rate.[498] In 2021, the overall life expectancy in Russia at birth was 70.06 years (65.51 years for males and 74.51 years for females),[499] and it had a very low infant mortality rate (5 per 1,000 live births).[500]

The principal cause of death in Russia are cardiovascular diseases.[501] Obesity is a prevalent health issue in Russia; most adults are overweight or obese.[502] However, Russia's historically high alcohol consumption rate is the biggest health issue in the country,[503] as it remains one of the world's highest, despite a stark decrease in the last decade.[504] Smoking is another health issue in the country.[505] The country's high suicide rate, although on the decline,[506] remains a significant social issue.[507]

Culture

Main article: Russian culture

Russian culture has been formed by the nation's history, its geographical location and its vast expanse, religious and social traditions, and Western influence.[508] Russian writers and philosophers have played an important role in the development of European literature and thought.[509][510] The Russians have also greatly influenced classical music,[511] ballet,[512] sport,[513] painting,[514] and cinema.[515] The nation has also made pioneering contributions to science and technology and space exploration.[516][517]

Russia is home to 30 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, 19 out of which are cultural; while 27 more sites lie on the tentative list.[518] The large global Russian diaspora has also played a major role in spreading Russian culture throughout the world. Russia's national symbol, the double-headed eagle, dates back to the Tsardom period, and is featured in its coat of arms and heraldry.[66] The Russian Bear and Mother Russia are often used as national personifications of the country.[519][520] Matryoshka dolls are considered a cultural icon of Russia.[521]

Holidays

Main article: Public holidays in Russia

Russia has eight—public, patriotic, and religious—official holidays.[522] The year starts with New Year's Day on 1 January, soon followed by Russian Orthodox Christmas on 7 January; the two are the country's most popular holidays.[523] Defender of the Fatherland Day, dedicated to men, is celebrated on 23 February.[524] International Women's Day on 8 March, gained momentum in Russia during the Soviet era. The annual celebration of women has become so popular, especially among Russian men, that Moscow's flower vendors often see profits of "15 times" more than other holidays.[525] Spring and Labour Day, originally a Soviet era holiday dedicated to workers, is celebrated on 1 May.[526]

Victory Day, which honours Soviet victory over Nazi Germany and the End of World War II in Europe, is celebrated as an annual large parade in Moscow's Red Square;[527] and marks the famous Immortal Regiment civil event.[528] Other patriotic holidays include Russia Day on 12 June, celebrated to commemorate Russia's declaration of sovereignty from the collapsing Soviet Union;[529] and Unity Day on 4 November, commemorating the 1612 uprising which marked the end of the Polish occupation of Moscow.[530]

There are many popular non-public holidays. Old New Year is celebrated on 14 January.[531] Maslenitsa is an ancient and popular East Slavic folk holiday.[532] Cosmonautics Day on 12 April, in tribute to the first human trip into space.[533] Two major Christian holidays are Easter and Trinity Sunday.[534]

Art and architecture

Main articles: Russian artists, Russian architecture, and List of Russian architects
Karl Bryullov, The Last Day of Pompeii (1833)
The Winter Palace served as the official residence of the Emperor of Russia.

Early Russian painting is represented in icons and vibrant frescos. In the early 15th-century, the master icon painter Andrei Rublev created some of Russia's most treasured religious art.[535] The Russian Academy of Arts, which was established in 1757, to train Russian artists, brought Western techniques of secular painting to Russia.[81] In the 18th century, academicians Ivan Argunov, Dmitry Levitzky, Vladimir Borovikovsky became influential.[536] The early 19th century saw many prominent paintings by Karl Briullov and Alexander Ivanov, both of whom were known for Romantic historical canvases.[537][538] Ivan Aivazovsky, another Romantic painter, is considered one of the greatest masters of marine art.[539]

In the 1860s, a group of critical realists (Peredvizhniki), led by Ivan Kramskoy, Ilya Repin and Vasiliy Perov broke with the academy, and portrayed the many-sided aspects of social life in paintings.[540] The turn of the 20th century saw the rise of symbolism; represented by Mikhail Vrubel and Nicholas Roerich.[541][542] The Russian avant-garde flourished from approximately 1890 to 1930; and globally influential artists from this era were El Lissitzky,[543] Kazimir Malevich, Natalia Goncharova, Wassily Kandinsky, and Marc Chagall.[544]

The history of Russian architecture begins with early woodcraft buildings of ancient Slavs, and the church architecture of Kievan Rus'.[545] Following the Christianization of Kievan Rus', for several centuries it was influenced predominantly by Byzantine architecture.[546] Aristotle Fioravanti and other Italian architects brought Renaissance trends into Russia.[547] The 16th-century saw the development of the unique tent-like churches; and the onion dome design, which is a distinctive feature of Russian architecture.[548] In the 17th-century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow and Yaroslavl, gradually paving the way for the Naryshkin baroque of the 1680s.[549]

After the reforms of Peter the Great, Russia's architecture became influenced by Western European styles. The 18th-century taste for Rococo architecture led to the splendid works of Bartolomeo Rastrelli and his followers. The most influential Russian architects of the eighteenth century; Vasily Bazhenov, Matvey Kazakov, and Ivan Starov, created lasting monuments in Moscow and Saint Petersburg and established a base for the more Russian forms that followed.[535] During the reign of Catherine the Great, Saint Petersburg was transformed into an outdoor museum of Neoclassical architecture.[550] Under Alexander I, Empire style became the de facto architectural style.[551] The second half of the 19th-century was dominated by the Neo-Byzantine and Russian Revival style.[552] In early 20th-century, Russian neoclassical revival became a trend.[553] Prevalent styles of the late 20th-century were Art Nouveau,[554] Constructivism,[555] and Socialist Classicism.[556]

Music

Main article: Music of Russia

Until the 18th-century, music in Russia consisted mainly of church music and folk songs and dances.[557] In the 19th-century, it was defined by the tension between classical composer Mikhail Glinka along with other members of The Mighty Handful, who were later succeeded by the Belyayev circle,[558] and the Russian Musical Society led by composers Anton and Nikolay Rubinstein.[559] The later tradition of Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, one of the greatest composers of the Romantic era, was continued into the 20th century by Sergei Rachmaninoff. World-renowned composers of the 20th century include Alexander Scriabin, Alexander Glazunov,[557] Igor Stravinsky, Sergei Prokofiev and Dmitri Shostakovich, and later Edison Denisov, Sofia Gubaidulina,[560] Georgy Sviridov,[561] and Alfred Schnittke.[560]

During the Soviet era, popular music also produced a number of renowned figures, such as the two balladeers—Vladimir Vysotsky and Bulat Okudzhava,[560] and performers such as Alla Pugacheva.[562] Jazz, even with sanctions from Soviet authorities, flourished and evolved into one of the country's most popular musical forms.[560] By the 1980s, rock music became popular across Russia, and produced bands such as Aria, Aquarium,[563] DDT,[564] and Kino;[565] the latter's leader Viktor Tsoi, was in particular, a gigantic figure.[566] Pop music has continued to flourish in Russia since the 1960s, with globally famous acts such as t.A.T.u.[567]

Literature and philosophy

Main articles: Russian literature and Russian philosophy
Leo Tolstoy (1828–1910), is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time, with works such as War and Peace.[568]
Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821–1881), one of the great novelists of all time, whose masterpieces include Crime and Punishment[569]

Russian literature is considered to be among the world's most influential and developed.[509] It can be traced to the Middle Ages, when epics and chronicles in Old East Slavic were composed.[570] By the Age of Enlightenment, literature had grown in importance, with works from Mikhail Lomonosov, Denis Fonvizin, Gavrila Derzhavin, and Nikolay Karamzin.[571] From the early 1830s, during the Golden Age of Russian Poetry, literature underwent an astounding golden age in poetry, prose and drama.[572] Romanticism permitted a flowering of poetic talent: Vasily Zhukovsky and later his protégé Alexander Pushkin came to the fore.[573] Following Pushkin's footsteps, a new generation of poets were born, including Mikhail Lermontov, Nikolay Nekrasov, Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy, Fyodor Tyutchev and Afanasy Fet.[571]

The first great Russian novelist was Nikolai Gogol.[574] Then came Ivan Turgenev, who mastered both short stories and novels.[575] Fyodor Dostoevsky and Leo Tolstoy soon became internationally renowned. Mikhail Saltykov-Shchedrin wrote prose satire,[576] while Nikolai Leskov is best remembered for his shorter fiction.[577] In the second half of the century Anton Chekhov excelled in short stories and became a leading dramatist.[578] Other important 19th-century developments included the fabulist Ivan Krylov,[579] non-fiction writers such as the critic Vissarion Belinsky,[580] and playwrights such as Aleksandr Griboyedov and Aleksandr Ostrovsky.[581][582] The beginning of the 20th century ranks as the Silver Age of Russian Poetry. This era had poets such as Alexander Blok, Anna Akhmatova, Boris Pasternak, and Konstantin Balmont.[583] It also produced some first-rate novelists and short-story writers, such as Aleksandr Kuprin, Nobel Prize winner Ivan Bunin, Leonid Andreyev, Yevgeny Zamyatin, Dmitry Merezhkovsky and Andrei Bely.[571]

After the Russian Revolution of 1917, Russian literature split into Soviet and white émigré parts. In the 1930s, Socialist realism became the predominant trend in Russia. Its leading figure was Maxim Gorky, who laid the foundations of this style.[584] Mikhail Bulgakov was one of the leading writers of the Soviet era.[585] Nikolay Ostrovsky's novel How the Steel Was Tempered has been among the most successful works of Russian literature. Influential émigré writers include Vladimir Nabokov,[586] and Isaac Asimov; who was considered one of the "Big Three" science fiction writers.[587] Some writers dared to oppose Soviet ideology, such as Nobel Prize-winning novelist Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, who wrote about life in the Gulag camps.[588]

Russian philosophy has been greatly influential. Alexander Herzen is known as one of the fathers of agrarian populism.[589] Mikhail Bakunin is referred to as the father of anarchism.[590] Peter Kropotkin was the most important theorist of anarcho-communism.[591] Mikhail Bakhtin's writings have significantly inspired scholars.[592] Helena Blavatsky gained international following as the leading theoretician of Theosophy, and co-founded the Theosophical Society.[593] Vladimir Lenin, a major revolutionary, developed a variant of communism known as Leninism.[594] Leon Trotsky, on the other hand, founded Trotskyism.[595] Alexander Zinoviev was a prominent philosopher in the second half of the 20th century.[596] Aleksandr Dugin, known for his fascist views, has been regarded as the "guru of geopolitics".[597]

Cuisine

See also: Russian cuisine

Russian cuisine has been formed by climate, cultural and religious traditions, and the vast geography of the nation; and it shares similarities with the cuisines of its neighbouring countries. Crops of rye, wheat, barley, and millet provide the ingredients for various breads, pancakes and cereals, as well as for many drinks. Bread, of many varieties,[598] is very popular across Russia.[599] Flavourful soups and stews include shchi, borsch, ukha, solyanka, and okroshka. Smetana (a heavy sour cream) and mayonnaise are often added to soups and salads.[600][601] Pirozhki,[602] blini,[603] and syrniki are native types of pancakes.[604] Beef Stroganoff,[605]: 266  Chicken Kiev,[605]: 320  pelmeni,[606] and shashlyk are popular meat dishes.[607] Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls (golubtsy) usually filled with meat.[608] Salads include Olivier salad,[609] vinegret,[610] and dressed herring.[611]

Russia's national non-alcoholic drink is kvass,[612] and the national alcoholic drink is vodka; its creation in the nation dates back to the 14th century.[613] The country has the world's highest vodka consumption,[614] while beer is the most popular alcoholic beverage.[615] Wine has become increasingly popular in Russia in the 21st century.[616] Tea has been popular in Russia for centuries.[617]

Mass media and cinema

Main articles: Media of Russia and Cinema of Russia

There are 400 news agencies in Russia, among which the largest internationally operating are TASS, RIA Novosti, Sputnik, and Interfax.[619] Television is the most popular medium in Russia.[620] Among the 3,000 licensed radio stations nationwide, notable ones include Radio Rossii, Vesti FM, Echo of Moscow, Radio Mayak, and Russkoye Radio. Of the 16,000 registered newspapers, Argumenty i Fakty, Komsomolskaya Pravda, Rossiyskaya Gazeta, Izvestia, and Moskovskij Komsomolets are popular. State-run Channel One and Russia-1 are the leading news channels, while RT is the flagship of Russia's international media operations.[620] Russia has the largest video gaming market in Europe, with over 65 million players nationwide.[621]

Russian and later Soviet cinema was a hotbed of invention, resulting in world-renowned films such as The Battleship Potemkin, which was named the greatest film of all time at the Brussels World's Fair in 1958.[622][623] Soviet-era filmmakers, most notably Sergei Eisenstein and Andrei Tarkovsky, would go on to become among of the world's most innovative and influential directors.[624][625] Eisenstein was a student of Lev Kuleshov, who developed the groundbreaking Soviet montage theory of film editing at the world's first film school, the All-Union Institute of Cinematography.[626] Dziga Vertov's "Kino-Eye" theory had a huge impact on the development of documentary filmmaking and cinema realism.[627] Many Soviet socialist realism films were artistically successful, including Chapaev, The Cranes Are Flying, and Ballad of a Soldier.[515]

The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema.[515] The comedies of Eldar Ryazanov and Leonid Gaidai of that time were immensely popular, with many of the catchphrases still in use today.[628][629] In 1961–68 Sergey Bondarchuk directed an Oscar-winning film adaptation of Leo Tolstoy's epic War and Peace, which was the most expensive film made in the Soviet Union.[515] In 1969, Vladimir Motyl's White Sun of the Desert was released, a very popular film in a genre of ostern; the film is traditionally watched by cosmonauts before any trip into space.[630] After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the Russian cinema industry suffered large losses—however, since the late 2000s, it has seen growth once again, and continues to expand.[631]

Sports

Main article: Sport in Russia

Football is the most popular sport in Russia.[633] The Soviet Union national football team became the first European champions by winning Euro 1960,[634] and reached the finals of Euro 1988.[635] Russian clubs CSKA Moscow and Zenit Saint Petersburg won the UEFA Cup in 2005 and 2008.[636][637] The Russian national football team reached the semi-finals of Euro 2008.[638] Russia was the host nation for the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup,[639] and the 2018 FIFA World Cup.[640] However, Russian teams are currently suspended from FIFA and UEFA competitions.[641]

Ice hockey is very popular in Russia, and the Soviet national ice hockey team dominated the sport internationally throughout its existence.[513] Bandy is Russia's national sport, and it has historically been the highest-achieving country in the sport.[642] The Russian national basketball team won the EuroBasket 2007,[643] and the Russian basketball club PBC CSKA Moscow is among the most successful European basketball teams.[644] The annual Formula One Russian Grand Prix was held at the Sochi Autodrom in the Sochi Olympic Park, until its termination following the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022.[645][646]

Historically, Russian athletes have been one of the most successful contenders in the Olympic Games.[513] Russia is the leading nation in rhythmic gymnastics; and Russian synchronised swimming is considered to be the world's best.[647] Figure skating is another popular sport in Russia, especially pair skating and ice dancing.[648] Russia has produced numerous prominent tennis players.[649] Chess is also a widely popular pastime in the nation, with many of the world's top chess players being Russian for decades.[650] The 1980 Summer Olympic Games were held in Moscow,[651] and the 2014 Winter Olympics and the 2014 Winter Paralympics were hosted in Sochi.[652][653] However, Russia has also had 43 Olympic medals stripped from its athletes due to doping violations, which is the most of any country, and nearly a third of the global total.[654]

The southernmost Kuril Islands have been the subject of a territorial dispute with Japan since their occupation by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.[2]
  2. ^ a b The Sreda Arena Atlas 2012 did not count the populations of two federal subjects of Russia where the majority of the population is Muslim, namely Chechnya and Ingushetia, which together had a population of nearly 2 million, thus the proportion of Muslims was possibly slightly underestimated.[7]
